items.title: The history of CSS
items.content:
Frontend Focus

#â€‹489 â€” May 5, 2021 | Read on the web

The History of CSS â€” Jay Hoffman returns for another instalment in his excellent web history series, this time looking at the backstory of CSS. The series so far has covered things such as search, browsers, web design, and more â€”Â all are well worth a read. Oh, and thereâ€™s also an audio version of this narrated by Jeremy Keith if youÂ fancy.

CSS-Tricks

The Humble <img> Element and Core Web Vitals â€” Images have always been a key part of the web (well, since HTML 2.0 anyway ;-) â€” they communicate ideas instantly, but they are also a lot heavier than text to load. As such, itâ€™s essential to get loading and displaying them right. Here's an excerpt from Addyâ€™s new book on the topic (also, check a free PDFÂ preview).

Addy Osmani

Nail the Fundamentals of Web Performance â€” Join Todd Gardner for an in-depth course on all things web perf. Youâ€™ll learn about new core web vitals metrics, such as cumulative layout shift, and how to improveÂ them.

Frontend Masters sponsor

New WebKit Features in Safari 14.1 â€” We mentioned this release in passing in last weekâ€™s issue, but hereâ€™s a blog post from the WebKit team outlining whatâ€™s new â€”Â such as Flexbox Gap support, individual CSS transform properties, the Paint Timing API, WebM support, andÂ more.

Jon Davis

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • Microsoft have joined the Bytecode Alliance to 'advance' WebAssembly.
  • Frontend Practice is a site that challenges you to recreate real websites as way to hone your frontend skills.
  • Throwback: Remember the CSS Zen Garden? It's now 18 years old.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

How to Create Actions for Selected Text With the Selection API â€” Click, drag, release: youâ€™ve just selected some text on a webpageâ€‰â€”â€‰a selection menu pops up with some options for what you may want to do next. Hereâ€™s how to makeÂ one.

Preethi Sam

Performance-Testing the Google I/O Site â€” Another solid performance review from Jake here, this time looking at how the Google I/O site fares on a 3G mobile connection. (Spoiler: Itâ€™s ratherÂ slow)

Jake Archibald

The State of CSS Cross-Browser Development â€” Thoughts on why cross-browser development is better today than ever before, and a look at what issues stillÂ remain.

Ahmad Shadeed

Trouble with Remote Pair Programming? Download Reveloâ€™s eBook â€” The future of work is here. Prepare yourself and your team for remoteÂ pairing.

Revelo sponsor

Understanding Design Systems: Designing Component APIs â€” â€œDesigners that understand how component APIs work can make more meaningful decisions when defining aÂ componentâ€

Eduardo Ferreira

Don't You Forget About Me: Overlooked Breakpoints in Responsive Design
Polypane

Top Metrics You Need to Understand When Measuring Frontend Performance

Variable Fonts in WordPress: How to Use Them and Why

The Evolution of Jamstack

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools and Resources

Iconic: A Free Set of 'Do-what-you-want' Pixel-Perfect Icons â€” 150+ SVG icons. Requires login to download or copy the code and the icons are searchable andÂ categorized.

James M & Orman C

CQFill: A Polyfill for CSS Container Queries â€” In case you were wondering, Container Queries have no browser support yet except Chrome behind a flag. Related: Bramus Van Damme takes a look at how it worksÂ here.

jonathan neal

A Better Way to Build Internal Tools

Retool sponsor

CSS Filters Generator: A Live Playground for CSS Filters â€” This online tool lets you easily generate cross-browser CSS to modify hue, saturation, brightness, contrast, etc. using CSS filters. Upload your own image or use theÂ example.

Michael Bollin

Eva.js: A Frontend Game Engine for Creating Interactive Game Projects â€” Includes components that are ready to use out-of-the-box and it uses PixiJS for performant WebGL rendering. Try it in this liveÂ playground.

EVA

QuickSnippets: Categorized Code Snippets Sourced from Tweets â€” Nicely laid out, searchable, and categorized for easy filtering. Note that the snippets are generally in images, so not the most accessible, but itâ€™s a niceÂ selection.

QuickSnippets

Font Subsetter: A Fast and Easy to Use Font Subset Generator

items.content:
Frontend Focus

#â€‹488 â€” April 28, 2021 | Read on the web

A Guide To Newly Supported, Modern CSS Pseudo-Class Selectors â€” The CSS Working Group Editorâ€™s Draft for Selectors Level 4 includes several pseudo-class selectors that already have proposal candidates in most modern browsers. This guide will cover ones that currently have the best support along with examples to demonstrate how you can start using themÂ today.

Stephanie Eckles

Learn How to Structure Your Remote Hiring Process â€” A new era of remote work suddenly arrived and managers need to enhance their recruiting process if they want to win the best talent for their companies. This guide shows you how GitLab, Zapier and other companies build thriving remoteÂ teams.

Revelo sponsor

Getting Started with CSS Custom Properties â€” Andy looks at just how useful Custom properties in CSS can be, â€œnot just for tokenising your CSS, but also for abstracting complexity and interactivity into smaller, easier to manage piecesâ€. This short guide will get you up to speed with how they work and how to useÂ them.

Andy Bell

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • The CSS Working Group has maintained a list of CSS mistakes that "should be corrected if anyone invents a time machine".
  • Here's another new 'browser' to put on your radar: Mighty. It's currently in early access and streams a cloud-hosted browser to your ownÂ machine.
  • In last week's issue we featured a round-up of links looking at Google's FLoC proposal â€” now GitHub is the latest to block FLoC across all GitHub Pages.
  • Safari 14.1 shipped this week, with support for Flexbox Gap, however you still need to provide a fallback, so here's Ahmad Shadeed with how to detect support.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Generating and Solving Sudokus in CSS â€” â€œI love to make CSS do stuff it shouldnâ€™tâ€. This is a fun look at just how to approach tackling such anÂ experiment.

Lee Meyer

How to Bake Layers of Accessibility Testing Into Your Process â€” Accessibility experts Kate Kalcevich and Mike Gifford introduce â€œlayered accessibility testingâ€, a practice of using a variety of tools/approaches at different stages in a product lifecycle to catch accessibility issues early (when itâ€™s easier and cheaper to fixÂ them).

Smashing Magazine

The Complete Guide to Google's Core Web Vitals Performance Metrics â€” A solid overview of all the key terms of Googleâ€™s performance metrics. We featured a handy guide along similar lines in last weekâ€™sÂ issue.

Craig Buckler

A Webpack Tutorial for Beginners: A Step-by-Step Guide â€” If youâ€™ve tried other bundler options but havenâ€™t looked into webpack (maybe because of the bigger learning curve), this introductory tutorial might be a good startingÂ point.

Louis Lazaris beginner

[Guide] The Truth About Developer Productivity Metrics â€” What you need to know to avoid weaponizing metrics for performance reviews, and use them to accelerate releasesÂ instead.

Sleuth sponsor

Customizing Tailwind CSS â€” A look at how to make Tailwind look different whilst â€œkeeping all the underlyingÂ goodiesâ€.

Ben Mann

How to Test Website Speed the Right Way â€” A step-by-step tutorial on how to properly run tests to ensure optimum page load times andÂ performance.

John Demian

The Making (and Potential Benefits) of a CSS Font â€” A way to render text without using any font atÂ all.

Levi Szekeres

Lighthouse Metrics: Global Performance Insights for Your Site â€” Enter a URL and this tool will give you Lighthouse scores based on different geographic locations (US East, EU North, Asia Pacific North, etc).

Lighthouse Metrics

Grid.js: An Advanced Table Control â€” A lightweight, advanced table plugin that can work alongside React, Angular, Vue, or, well, nothing. Check out some of the examples for more on how to use it. It uses Preact under theÂ hood.

Afshin Mehrabani

Uncut: An Open Source Typeface Catalogue, Focusing On Somewhat Contemporary Type â€” Currently features about 50 fonts that are available for direct download, and it seems the fonts are all free or openÂ source.

uncut

WinBox: An HTML5 Window Manager for the Web â€” Very thoroughly documented and works pretty well, but feels a bit like Web-based UI experiments of 10+ years ago..? GitHubÂ repo.

WinBox

items.title: An in-depth guide to Core Web Vitals
items.content:
Frontend Focus

#â€‹487 â€” April 21, 2021 | Read on the web

An In-Depth Guide To Measuring Core Web Vitals â€” How are Core Web Vitals measured? How do you know your fixes have had the desired effect and when will you see the results in Google Search Console? Barry Pollard takes aÂ look. Jess B Peck's The Almost-Complete Guide to Cumulative Layout Shift is another useful guide digging deeper into oneÂ aspect.

Smashing Magazine

Introducing CSS Grid Inspector in Safari â€” Safari now has a CSS Grid Layout Inspector (you can try it as of Safari Technology Preview 123), this post looks at how to useÂ it.

Razvan Caliman (WebKit)
